entry.answer: Shakuntala's mother is Menaka, an apsara (celestial nymph), and her father is the sage Vishwamitra. entry.answer: Dushyanta rejects Shakuntala because she is not of royal birth, as he is bound by societal norms. This leads to her exile and separation from him, but later, when he recognizes her as his wife through a ring, he takes responsibility for their son, Bharata.

entry.answer: Yayati, seeking to enjoy worldly pleasures, transfers his youth to Pururava so he can indulge in desires. This act symbolizes the temporary nature of worldly pleasures and the burden of responsibility. Pururava later becomes a righteous king, while Yayati faces the consequences of his choices.
